level.inv.name: INV (NOT)
level.inv.description: The inverter (NOT gate) is the simplest logic gate. It outputs the opposite of its input: when input is 0, output is 1, and vice versa. Inverters are fundamental building blocks used in almost every digital circuit, from flip-flops to complex processors. Build it using a single NAND gate by connecting both inputs together.
level.and.name: AND
level.and.description: The AND gate outputs 1 only when ALL inputs are 1. It's used for combining conditions - like checking if multiple requirements are met simultaneously. In processors, AND gates are used in address decoding, masking operations, and control logic. Hint: NAND is 'NOT AND', so to make AND, you need to invert the NAND output.
level.or.name: OR
level.or.description: The OR gate outputs 1 when ANY input is 1. It's essential for selecting between options or detecting if at least one condition is true. OR gates are used in interrupt handling, bus arbitration, and error detection circuits. Hint: Use De Morgan's law - OR can be built by inverting all inputs to a NAND gate.
level.xor.name: XOR
level.xor.description: The XOR (exclusive OR) gate outputs 1 when inputs are DIFFERENT. It's the heart of binary arithmetic - used to calculate the sum bit in adders. XOR is also used for parity checking, data encryption, and toggle operations. You can build it using the gates you've already created: AND, OR, and INV.
level.half_adder.name: Half Adder
level.half_adder.description: The half adder is the first step toward building a calculator! It adds two single bits and produces a Sum and a Carry output. The sum is 1 when inputs differ (that's XOR!), and carry is 1 when both inputs are 1 (that's AND!). Half adders are building blocks for full adders and multi-bit arithmetic units.
level.full_adder.name: Full Adder
level.full_adder.description: The full adder extends the half adder by accepting a carry-in from a previous stage. This allows chaining multiple full adders to add numbers of any size! A 32-bit processor uses 32 full adders connected together. You can build it using two half adders and an OR gate for the carry-out.
level.mux.name: 2-to-1 MUX
level.mux.description: The multiplexer (MUX) is a data selector. It chooses one of multiple inputs and forwards it to the output. A 2-to-1 MUX has two data inputs (D0, D1), one select input (S), and one output. When S=0, output equals D0; when S=1, output equals D1. MUXes are everywhere in CPUs - used for data routing, ALU input selection, and building complex logic. You can build it using AND, OR, and INV gates.
level.demux.name: 1-to-2 DEMUX
level.demux.description: The demultiplexer (DEMUX) is the opposite of a MUX. It takes one data input and routes it to one of multiple outputs based on a select signal. A 1-to-2 DEMUX has one data input (D), one select input (S), and two outputs (Y0, Y1). When S=0, Y0=D and Y1=0; when S=1, Y0=0 and Y1=D. DEMUXes are used for data distribution, memory address decoding, and signal routing in digital systems.
level.decoder.name: 2-to-4 Decoder
level.decoder.description: The decoder converts a binary number to a one-hot code where exactly one output is HIGH. A 2-to-4 decoder has 2 inputs and 4 outputs. Input 00 activates output Y0, input 01 activates Y1, and so on. Decoders are essential in memory systems for address decoding, instruction decoding in CPUs, and seven-segment display drivers. Build it using AND gates and inverters - each output needs a unique combination of inputs.
level.encoder.name: 4-to-2 Encoder
level.encoder.description: The encoder is the opposite of a decoder. It converts a one-hot input (where exactly one input is active) to its binary representation. A 4-to-2 encoder has 4 inputs (I3-I0) and 2 outputs. When I0 is HIGH, output is 00; when I1 is HIGH, output is 01; when I2 is HIGH, output is 10; when I3 is HIGH, output is 11. Encoders are used in keyboards, interrupt handling, and data compression circuits.
level.dff.name: D Flip-Flop
level.dff.description: The D flip-flop (or D latch) is the fundamental building block of digital memory. It has a data input (D), a clock/enable input (CLK), and an output (Q). When CLK is HIGH, the latch is 'transparent' and Q follows D. When CLK goes LOW, Q holds its last value. This level tests the transparent behavior - when CLK=1, Q must equal D. Build it using NAND gates: you'll need a pair of cross-coupled NANDs for the SR latch core, plus input gating.
level.register.name: 1-bit Register
level.register.description: A register extends the D flip-flop by adding a load enable (LD) signal. The register only updates when BOTH the clock (CLK) AND load enable (LD) are HIGH. This allows selective updating of stored values - essential for CPU registers where you don't want every clock cycle to overwrite data. Inputs are D (data), CLK (clock), and LD (load enable). When CLK=1 AND LD=1, output Q equals D. Use your DFF component and add logic to gate the clock with the load enable.
level.register4b.name: 4-bit Register
level.register4b.description: The 4-bit register stores a nibble (4 bits) of data. It has four data inputs (D0-D3), a clock (CLK), a load enable (LD), and four outputs (Q0-Q3). When CLK=1 AND LD=1, all four outputs follow their corresponding inputs simultaneously. This is the building block for CPU registers, program counters, and data buffers. Build it using four 1-bit registers working in parallel, sharing the same CLK and LD signals.
level.ram16b.name: 16-bit RAM
level.ram16b.description: RAM (Random Access Memory) combines registers with address decoding to create addressable storage. This 16-bit RAM has 4 memory locations, each storing 4 bits. Inputs: A0-A1 (2-bit address selecting one of 4 locations), D0-D3 (4-bit data input), WE (write enable), and CLK. Outputs: Q0-Q3 (4-bit data output). When WE=1 and CLK=1, data is written to the selected address and simultaneously appears on outputs. Use your 4-bit registers and a 2-to-4 decoder to build this.
